Pop Team Epic is an incredibly dividing series. People either write joke reviews about how it's "saving anime" and is "absolutely perfect", and some claim it to be nothing more than poorly executed jokes and bad shitposting. There doesn't seem to be a center view of this series. I, personally, actually really respect Pop Team Epic and think it's pretty good, but only to the right people. Let me explain.
STORY: 3
Let's not beat around the bush here - it's' vignettes. It has no semblance of a story. There's not really a continuity. There are parts of the episode that are longer than the rest thatdo have plots, but they're not connected and don't really service each other at all.


ART: 10

Look, I know what you're thinking. You're thinking, "You're actually giving Art such a high score for a vignette series of shitposts"? And the answer is absolutely yes. The main reason why I respect Pop Team Epic and what it does so much is because of how much it throws things at the wall and does surreal things. Art is absolutely no exception to this rule. Throughout the series, Pop Team Epic does an absolute shitload of different art styles and animation styles. There's 2D animation in several art styles, 3D animation, Stop-Motion Animation, Puppetry, Sand Art, Live-Action Skits, and I think a lot more if I were to give myself more time to think. Hell, the episode "Hellshake Yano" has a long, creatively animated scene where well-cut and layered pages in notebooks are the animation for the segment, and it's unironically incredible to watch due to just how well-executed it is. Similarly to The Amazing World of Gumball, a show airing in the West, I hold it very close to my heart and find it incredibly cool to see so many different forms of animation and art in one show. It shows that the creators are having a lot of fun, and I really like that.


SOUND: 10

Juuuust like my Art section, the main reason why I put this on here is due to just how much they do with sound in this series. Pipimi and Popuko each have at least 10 different Seiyuus in both the male and female voice acting camp. And these aren't just interns looking for their big shot in the world - these are voice acting veterans who have worked on big shows like One Piece or Dragon Ball. It makes me cackle with delight when I recognize a voice actor as they say some stupid shit coming out of the mouth of a schoolgirl. Not to mention, they also throw in things like music videos and even French, spoken by actual French voice actors. Another part of the show I really like is when they throw in flubbed lines or voice actor laughs - You hear it a lot from the male seiyuus in transitions between vignettes. These vignettes can also have different lines, jokes, or comedic delivery depending on the male or female versions, giving them more surprising comedic moments as well. It also has a suuuper good OP and a cute ED, and the great thing is that it also throws in remixes of the Opening, Sound-Versions like a Jojo's Bizarre Adventure Opening, even alternate songs for openings like in episodes 1 and 11. There's a lot done on the sound and visual front alike, so I believe they deserve the same score.


CHARACTER: 5

Okay, so there's no real character writing here. Characters are here solely to set up jokes. While Pipimi TENDS to be the more stoic, voice of reason character over the bombastic and crude Popuko, it's not exactly consistent.


ENJOYMENT: 9

While not all the jokes landed, I had an absolute blast watching this series. I was watching one episode with a friend who claimed he had never heard me laugh that loud before after, like, 3 years of friendship or so. (By the way, that was episode 2. Episode 2 is absolutely a riot.) I also do understand a tad bit of Japanese, so maybe I could catch something in a Japanese pun that most people wouldn't get, but not consistently. It's a grab bag of comedy that, in my opinion, hits far more than it misses.


OVERALL: 8

Pop Team Epic is a mixed bag of comedy that has a lot of love poured into it, and you can tell the team behind it is having a ridiculous amount of fun. While its fast-paced, surrealist, vignette-style comedic scenes may not be funny to some people, I had a lot of fun while watching this.

This amazing anime has unfortunately ended (possibly with a second season coming) after 12 episodes. What can be said about the anime that hasn't already been said. It follows the everyday adventures of two (kind of cutesy drawn) girls, Popuko and Pipimi with absurd comedy that has a LOT of references and parodies. The story is there but it's so complicated and has such and amazing character development that you will be thrilled every time. The artstyle, while simplistic at times, is beautifully drawn and animated giving an air to the characters. And the soundtrack is simply amazing with an awesomely crafted opening and ending.I enjoyed every second of it and I'm sure you will enjoy it too.\n

This anime is a work of satirical genius. From episode one, we have all these amazing references and jabs to other popular animes, and in episode twelve, we have jabs to the people who made the series themselves.
The series uses a wide variety of animation styles, from the usual ones by Kamikaze Douga to the amazingly bad Bobunemimimmi ones, which I say is amazingly bad because it literally satirises itself.
The ending theme halfway through the series changes from the normal ending to Popuko and Pipimi dissing the series before going on and singing. That's another key in this satirical genius.
The voice acting changes from thestandard female voices to male character voices, which again, is amazingly great at satirising the series. And not only that, the voices actors are also connected, so the voices you hear come from another series, which is amazing.\n\n
It's kinda amazing how that King Records hasn't been sued over this yet, especially since there are so many jabs at other series.

Pop Team Epic is a wild experience.
If I learned anything while watching, it’s that anime is made for Japanese people by Japanese people. Even though I’m not a 日本人, I love this anime very much and it’s one of the funniest ones I’ve seen in years. Not because it’s dumb (even though it really is), but because it’s also smart (and it really is). It’s easy to dismiss Pop Team Epic as being nothing more than a meme-fest, trolling piece of junk, but by assuming that you would be doing yourself and this series a big disservice. It’s ridiculous and while virtually all anime are,this one uses its lunacy for its advantage. Every facet of this anime is bursting with creativity, references, weirdness, and joy.   


Hoshiiro Girldrop immediately welcomes the viewer and gives way to this colorful world. The catchy OP by Sumire Uesaka in episode 2 sets the perfect tone for what the anime is about. Combined with the simple art style, strong voice acting and humor, my interest in the series has only grown stronger and will keep me rewatching, just to experience it one more time. 2018 is without a shadow of a doubt a wonderful year because of this show’s existence.  


Like the manga it’s based off of, there is no central story. Instead, there is an abundance of skits involving two junior high school girls, Popuko and Pipimi. They both have an attitude, tend to not follow any form of logic and flip people off. While there is variety regarding the skits, most of them involve references to anime, tropes, video games and Japanese pop culture. There are even times when Pop Team Epic references itself. Some of them are probably not going to be recognizable to anyone outside of Japan. There are some widely known ones though such as Totoro, Earth, Wind & Fire, Skyrim (there’s a Pipimi mod out there now), Guardians of the Galaxy, Pokemon, and Super Mario.    


The actual time of the show is a little bit deceiving. While it is 20 something minutes, the episodes are repeated so it’s actually about 12 minutes long, just with different voice actors. One segment features Popuko and Pipimi with male voices and the other with female. While the true voices are actually the women, viewers might ask “why do men voice the main characters?”. Because in the manga, there’s a strip where Popuko and Pipimi muse about who should voice them if they get an anime adaption. They decide it should be two famous male voice actors because of how absurd it would be if it happened. This is probably the only constant, but there’s a routine of a different pair of voice actors for every episode. It does give a different approach to the same premise. There definitely is a large pool of talent and if you’ve watched a lot of anime, most of them will be recognizable. One example is Ryusei Nakao and Norio Wakamoto who are the voices of Freiza and Cell in Dragon Ball Z, respectively. It might seem like a waste of time to watch the exact same thing twice, but if you’re fan you should already have known what you were in for. 


There’s an infamous segment called Bob Team Epic. It’s drawn/animated in such a hideous and offmodel manner, but strangely, it doesn’t feel out of place. It actually has its own charm and even expands on the manga strips in its own unique way such as the “Are you angry?” skit where Popuko repeatedly punches Pipimi. Only this one doesn’t end with the former punching the latter, she not only repeatedly punches her, she punches her harder, slams her and eventually turns her into pickled radish. When asked again if she’s angry, Pipimi still isn’t. What’s the point of this? I don’t know, but what I do know is if everyone was as stoic as Pipimi the world would be a better place.


Speaking of the art, the animators really capture Bkub’s style down to a T. The animation is diverse and crisp and my favorite parts involve the felt toy dance sequences of the girls singing to pop songs. Other styles used are CGI, in real life events and the aforementioned Bob Team Epic’s rough art. The sound is also off the wall. The are times when dulcet dramatic music plays in the background during what is supposed to be the most mundane events. The experimentation is able to give the anime more of an identity and despite all this randomness in technique, I’m surprised how everything still manages to fit together so well.


The cover of the first volume of the manga shows both girls giving the viewer a double one finger salute, and I’m sure that’s how the strangest anime duo view anyone who hates the series. Pop Team Epic is so self aware that it doesn’t care if you love it or if you hate it, you’re still going to be taking the time out of your day talking about it regardless. It’s pure, unadulterated fun. It doesn’t always make sense, but it doesn’t have to. That’s also one of its greatest strengths, it just doesn’t care and does whatever it wants. That’s something I can wholeheartedly respect when it comes to anyone or anything really. 


Pop Team Epic is a breath of fresh air. It is the cure to the humdrum times that’s been around for a number of anime seasons. Not only is it the highlight of 2018 of anything, it is truly an achievement in the medium and the kind every generation to come should experience. Unfortunately, all good things must come to an end. However, there’s a ton of material that can be made and a multitude of ideas to go through so this anime can go on for a long time if it wanted to. Washu-kamisama bless you, Bkub Okawa! And may she also bless Pop Team Epic forever and ever. Amen.

I started a draft of a full, proper review of Poputepikku, describing the skits I liked and the ones I didn't, ultimately calling it a "hit-or-miss" sort of thing like many sketch comedies are. It would honestly be some kind of miracle if a comedy that relied on sketches could maintain the same level of quality all the way through. It does at least have more "hits" than a lot of American sketch comedies, especially if you're a fan of nonsensical humor.
But then I imagined Popuko reading my review, tearing through the screen, and asking me "Ah, you are motherfucker?"
So I'm just going to goahead and tell you that Poputepikku is worth a watch, especially if you're bored with traditional anime comedy. Some sketches might have just flown over my head - I highly recommend going for HIDIVE's subtitles rather than Crunchyroll/HorribleSubs' if you're going to watch the sub. I saw screencaps of HIDIVE's version that were way funnier.

I notice a lot of people either give this anime a stellar review or tend to just shit post all over it. I can agree that this anime is very polarized in that you either love it or hate it and there really is no middle ground.
I want to just start off by saying that I read the description and was intrigued by the description of it as an "absurdist" work. So I turned on episode one and asked myself "What in the name of Hell am I watching?" and I almost dropped in right then. It wasn't at all what I was expecting andI thought it was a trainwreck that had already happened. But I followed my general rule and waited for the next two or three episodes to come out and see where it went. Over that time I grew to accept what the anime was trying to do, and I also feel that the anime has come a long way in really figuring out how it needs to execute itself for maximum effect. I give it an overall seven out of ten because, while I seriously enjoy watching this, there really isn't much else past being an absurdist comedy piece. No, there is no linear storyline. If you watched through the episodes, you'll notice that it's supposed to resemble short comic strips, with the anime being a series of small skits rather than one long continuous story. The intro even has a couple segments where the background is like a pile of newspaper comic section clippings featuring the characters of the anime. I really like how this was executed on screen and I feel they did a good job of it. However, this kind of thing is very limited in terms of what it can do, and eventually it becomes just short skits over and over again every week, even if I do get a good laugh each episode. The reason the score is low for me has nothing to do with the animation, which fits well with the intention of the anime, or with lack of a plot, which is the entire point and the anime wouldn't be as good if it had the same goal but with a single coherent plot, but the low score is attributable to the fact that there isn't any room for growth and development, so the anime eventually stagnates and gets repetitive.\n\n
There are definitely better anime this season and this past year, much better comedies and the like. If you want a serious recommendation from me for a comedy this season, I might recommend something like Mitsuboshi Colors or Slow Start, but I will say that this anime is one that shouldn't be looked over simply because of a bad review or because it isn't the best of the season. I think it deserves a chance, and because I gave it one I ended up actually enjoying it, and I think you might enjoy it as well.

pop team epic is not for everyone, though anime that IS aimed toward everyone tends to be too safe and therefore irredeemable trash. this anime is intentionally random, with multiple skits that don't take place in one single continuous timeline. some parts look like professional anime, others look like they were drawn by a drunk middle schooler who is trying their best to dishonor their family. the anime also comes in two halves, the second of which is (almost) exactly the same except the schoolgirls are voiced by two adult men. some of the skits poke fun at pop culture and anime, some skits borderon non sequitur, and others are just truly bizarre (ie., bacon eating itself.) the one consistency i've been able to find is that they're all wonderfully absurd. if all these things sound great to you, you'll love it. if not, then it's best you look elsewhere.

the only thing that concerns me is that internet people have forgotten the difference between a joke and a meme.


this was hard to rate because of the story-telling limitations of skits and the intentional inconsistencies in quality, so i instead judged it in the context of "if it was horrible to make you laugh, it doesn't count." then i gave up and gave it straight tens because life is too short for this.

Pop Team Epic is a very polarizing anime. Right off the bat, you either like the show or you don't like the show. It's humor is very specific and might not resonate with everyone who watches it. It's definitely not a 'universal' show that anyone can pick up and enjoy.
That being said, I think if do enjoy what Pop Team Epic does with its humor and style, then you'll end up loving the show.
Structure:
  Pop Team Epic is structured a lot like old Adult Swim comedy shows or bumps: quick (most of the time), bizarre, and with a punchline that can last less thana second. Being that it's based on a four panel manga strip series, a lot of the segments are short and to the point. Some segments might last longer, with the majority of the longer running ones really just being short segments under the same narrative, but for the most part the segments are over before they outstay their welcome. This is to the benefit of the show, as, because if the type of humor the show has, the segments can be hit or miss. I found myself bored during some segments and laughing hard a few seconds later when it's changed the segment. Because the show is really just a bunch of clips, if one isn't jiving with you there's no harm in skipping it.

  Despite its full anime episode length on Crunchyroll, it's really split in half between the female and male voice actors. This is a very controversial choice and didn't sit well with a lot of people. I remember watching the first episode and getting confused on why I was watching the same clips again. They actually do change some of the dialogue or jokes around between the two halves, so they're not complete carbon copies. The episodes don't feel like they're meant to be watched all the way through, rather you should pick which voice acting you want to listen to and choose that half. If there's a good segment, sometimes it's worth watching it again with the opposite voice actors.

  I heard someone say that this show would work better as TV bumps (like Adult swim) that cycled through the clips and which voice actors they were using. So you might see a clip, and then later in the day see the same clip but with with the different voice actors. That's the unfortunate part about how Pop Team Epic is structured. It doesn't work well being aired tradionally, but that's what they have to work with. 




Art:


  A lot of people discredit PTE for being a meme show or just a big 'shitpost' because of its simple style and hit or miss humor, but the show is worth a lot more than that. I do love seeing the little segments posted individually online and because of how relatable some of the humor is the show fits right in gif posts or Facebook reaction posts and just all around jives with the post-Vine internet culture, but a lot of people miss the heart behind the show. It's not just "lolrandom" or "memes". There's some impressive animation and talent behind the show; some clips have animation that seem like they have no right being that good. There's a few segments where they use custom felted dolls for stop motion, one segment is animated in sand (yes, the beach kind), and a very impressive skit that's animated with two notebooks held by two dudes voice acting at the same time. A lot of creativity is put into the show, and I think it's worth acknowledging.




Characters:


While the two main characters, Popuko and Pipimi, might not seem like anything but vehicles for whatever joke needs to happen, there's a lot of hidden character within them. For one, they love eachother very much (most of the time). This show has some of the cutest scenes of just two people being cute and loving to eachother (and sometimes smacking them across the room). It's hard to get a read on their personalities, given that it's a gag show with no overarching narrative, but both the girls have their own unique personality traits that compliment perfectly with each other.




Overall, I think this show is fun, quirky, and worth your time if it resonates with you. It can be both bizarre and relatable at the same time, and the gags tend not to overstay their welcome. It's not a perfect show and is t for everyone, but I think it's wrong to discredit all the heart and creativity the show has to offer just because it can come off a certain way.

Art: 7
Bob Team Epic (ボブネミミッミ) is outstanding. If you like shows like Superjail! and other comically repulsive and ugly distortions in animation, then this is the right up your alley. I find this hilarious just in appearance alone. The simplistic nature of the rest of the animation is a platform that elevates the craziness of this segment's absurdity.
Story: 5
It's a hit or miss sketch comedy.
Sound: 5
Nothing to note.
Character: 6
The voice acting is diverse enough to augment the parodies and other comical references. I enjoy how the VA's can convey so many different personalities through voices alone in this show, which is pretty critical to thesuccess in such a short sketch format.\n\n
Enjoyment: 6\n
I only enjoy a fraction of the skits. Bob Team Epic is the highlight. \n

Y'all ever seen the Eric Andre Show? It's like that but anime. 
It's hard to translate a 4koma into a fully animated feature, its even harder when the 4koma has absolutely no obligation to have any sort of continuity or storyline. Pop Team Epic is what happens when you try to take Vines and internet skits and stretch it into a full 25 min time slot. The timing is incredibly fast past, barely giving the viewer any time to think or react to the scenes occurring. The humor is very Japanese, relying hard on what is assumed to be common background knowledge on common TVand movie tropes. 


Nothing in this show is to be taken seriously and the show seems to be under no obligation to even explain itself. The best bits are the longer ones, with a set up and pay off. The more polarizing parts are going to be the parts that often rely on wordplay or surrealism to be funny. Some don't even have jokes, with the lack of a punchline being the punchline itself. Bob Team Epic parts are the worst. 


This is not something you should binge watch, you'll get an aneurysm. The episodes are divided into two parts, one with mostly female voice actors and the other with male voice actors. Maybe the voice actors are from famous shows and that's why they don't seem to have the same one twice, but I wouldn't know. 


There are legitimately funny and humorous moments, like the Earth Wind and Fire parody, and the more traditional comedy skits. But if you're looking for a classic comedy you can sit down and watch after a long day, this is the wrong place. 


This show gets better. The first few episodes were rough, but once it gets to about the 4 or 5th episode, it really starts to get into it's stride. Stick with it, it does get better.

First of all, finding this anime was quite the journey which I think is what made the show so enjoyable for me and my friend. It started off with seeing tons of fan art on Twitter, which was all very cute but I was confused, another one of those art trends? It looks funny, it looks weird. One day someone posted the "lets pop together" music skit on Twitter and I though oh that's where its from, its a music video. I told my friend about it and searched it up on YouTube. I then found a series of VERY short skits, then I thoughoh its some kind of YouTuber series of short skits. That's when my friend said wait a minute, its an anime, a whole anime. After constantly being surprised and confused, I was amazed, how the hell is this an anime, seriously? We have to watch this.


I can totally understand why people wouldn't enjoy this show, it's very random out of place humour, all in a line. Some of the jokes are weird and some of them are funny, it all depends on how you look at it. I can say I enjoyed the show a lot with my friend but I really did not like those 'bob team ebic' sections (the ugly paint ones). However some of them were extremely creative and some of the references got to me and made me laugh. 


There is no story, the whole show is very short random skits put together. There is a lot of parody scenes and poking fun at other series and you either love it or you hate it. At the end of the day you only need to see one episode to figure out if you'll enjoy the show or not. The episodes are also rather short, which makes them easy to watch since they are 10 minutes long each, one female dub and one male dub, so pick your poison.


If you enjoy the humour, It is a refreshing show to watch in small 10 minute bursts, if you don't then I think you'd want to drop this one because every episode has different parodies and jokes but follows the same kind of pattern.

If you perchance definitely are considering watching this amalgamation of shitposts, you might basically have a gander at this really simple but amusing question. Who really am myself kidding in a subtle way. In the vicinity of first myself didn''t specifically feel thy require to particularly compose a letter on a paper a review for a actually short series kind of such as this, so who generally am myself kidding in a for all intents as well as purposes colossal way.But as myself completed thy last episode myself began to specifically realize not only did myself sit through as well as actually watched thy series to thy end, but myself actually was reaching for aspirin in a first aid kit near by.

I enjoyed Pop Team Epic (Poputepipikku) the same way I enjoy memes, in moderation. Pop Team is essentially memes the anime. This isn't a bad thing, the quick nature of jokes is lol XD random but some of them are reoccurring and the references can be on point. The translation from 4-koma to anime was actually extremely successful, no great changes in tone.
There's an overarching story which pops in and can be amusing. Yeah, recommended if you like Nichijou, or 4-komas. If you like more sophisticated and built up jokes then it won't be your thing. To be fair the jokes can be hit ormiss, I disliked the in between sections personally.\n

Overall, wouldn't watch again, I know the jokes now. But want to watch or continue, give it a shot.

Story & Characters: 10/10
Pop Team Epic's story is a subject of intense speculation and mystery. It's internal workings and deeper ramifications are barely understood, even to the team of neckbearded, waifu-signalling, 4chan-browsing, basement-dwelling troglodytes who conceived it. It is a loose assemblage of obscure pop culture references held together with spit and cum, and the most fitting analogy for the show's humor and flow is a gacha game. Most of the time, you'll be getting shit. But once in a while, you understand an extremely obscure reference or an insanely on-point parody that makes you feel as if the series is counting you in asone of the "cool kids." You keep coming back to get that shot of dopamine that makes your nipples tingle like a furry at the annual American Kennel Club. Your enjoyment of this series is directly proportional to how many references and parodies you catch, which is proportional to how long you've immersed yourself in this cesspool we call a pop culture. One thing for sure, though is that anyone who rates this show lower than a 9 is a mouth-breathing, soy-eating basic bitch boomer who has been living under a rock and does not understand quirky random millennial humor at its very best. It is a meme that has transcended all boundaries of reason and logic, has become so """"""ironic"""""" that it is immune to criticism and scrutiny. It doesn't have any proper setup or punchlines because it doesn't need any. It is the beacon of an era; the battle cry of a generation. Just when we thought dank memes cannot get any more obtuse and self-referencing, Pop Team Epic one ups the game by being something akin to a psychedelic social experiment, where the result is a joke that everyone finds funny, but no one understands. Everyone is in on the joke, but no one knows what the punchline is, and I dare not say anymore at risk of ruining the punchline if I haven't already.


The narrative that Pop Team Epic is pushing, while taken at face value, may seem trite and meaningless, but if one were to take a step back and look at the bigger picture, the pieces start clicking into place. In the first place, what is it trying to do? To fuck with the audience at every twist and turn, with every picosecond of its runtime. Why does it fuck with us like this? Because it literally markets itself as an edgy self-aware ironic dank meme. It is an anime that parades and ridicules itself on Twitter with the #kusoanime tag to draw attention to its subversiveness. The key visual for the anime announcement literally has the two main characters saying that the publisher for the manga will regret turning it into an anime. And strangely, this form of marketing worked. Not only did it manage to gather the entire japanese twitter community under its banner of flippant self-awareness, but it has also become something akin to an urban legend on western message boards and forums. It has a nothing short of an abusive relationship with its (ironic) fanbase, where everything it says and does is buried underneath so many layers of irony that its true intentions can never be discerned. Who is in on the meme and who is not? Is the season 2 announcement legit or are they just ironically cockslapping us like they always do? The charm of Pop Team Epic, aka its over-the-top self-awareness, has the mythical quality of being applicable to just about anything it does, suspending fan reactions in indefinite limbo, and fans actually like that. This is absolute genius. Every step of the way was calculated, and the marketing and production committees knew exactly what they were doing, even if the people they were marketing to didn't.


Art: 8/10

Pop Team Epic toes the line between pissing on our eyelids and showing us colors for the first time. Just when you think it's settled on an artstyle, it cockslaps you with something like Hellshake Yano, which, by the way, is one of the most batshit insane things I've ever seen in all my years of watching anime. Some dudes actually had to write, draw, choreograph, rehearse, and perform that shit. It wholly captures the flippant style and spirit of the manga, and leaves me with no complaints whatsoever. Actually, I do have two complaint: the BobbuNeMiMiMi segments look like dogshit, and the producers pussied out on the episode length and each episode is technically only 10 minutes long. But then again, both of those are not weaknesses but are actually strengths of Pop Team Epic, when you take into account what it's trying to do.


Sound: 8/10

Sound is one of the departments where Pop Team Epic really makes the most of its medium. The wildly inconsistent voice acting and sound design kept things interesting, and I actually enjoyed hearing some of my favorite female seiyuus like Mimori Suzuko and Taketatsu Ayana scream, shout, and bark at the top of their lungs for a really expensive shitpost.


Enjoyment: 9/10


Overall: 9/10

Every episode had me laughing to the point of crying from start to finish, with my favorite segment of them all easily being the one with the Skyline GT-R. With the assortment of different art styles and over-the-top humor, I thoroughly enjoyed this one. I also found it reallyinteresting that the block repeated with two different voice actors, and that there were minute differences in dialogue in them that one might not catch upon first viewing unless you're really paying attention. That being said, this one's unique style puts it leaps and bounds in front of everything else in terms of uniqueness. And let me tell you, the experience definitely pairs well with a bottle of Absolut at the ready. ^w^

The show is a mish-mash of short skits, small gags, and odd music videos all of which are highly referential or incredibly odd and out there.  It wields pop-culture, memes, and tropes with the delicacy of a man beating your head in with a baseball bat. This is it's greatest strength, but also it's greatest weakness. If you have at least minor credentials in online shit-posting, Japanese and Western genres, memes and culture then Pop Team Epic will probably be a delight to you. But if you aren't at least somewhat versed in these things then many of the jokes will pass you byand seem like pure randomness. Even when you do have an extensive knowledge in all things Pop-Culture sometimes the jokes stray a bit too far into random territory or pure reference with no twist to make it interesting. 


The show however is always fast paced and fun and if one part doesn't bring you a smile or laugh you won't have to wait long for the next attempt. 

I think the show truly comes alive during genre skits. These are usually longer sections where the show picks a genre of film or show and embraces it's tropes while poking fun at them. It's a nice little dissection where you get to see a genre taken to it's silliest and strangest extremes.


If you enjoy meta-humor, references and strangeness then this is a great show for you.

Pop Team Epic seems to be the type of anime (or manga) that people either love or hate, so I was surprised to find myself impartial. 
None of the jokes and punchlines really made me laugh, although they did manage to wrangle a few smiles out of me. At the same time, I wasn't bored, and I had no problems watching to the end of the anime. I've never really got black humour and non-sequitur humour and after watching this, I can safely say that it's not the style of humour I enjoy. 
At the same time, I don't regret watching it. It has areally interesting format and it's something I've never seen before. If you have some time to kill, I'd definitely recommend giving it a go, because there are some pretty cool segments. It was also fun picking out all the pop references!

Are you mad?
If you dislike absurdist humour that’s often bashed for being “random” then your experience with Pop Team Epic will  probably be a negative one. But I still urge you to try at least one episode before writing it off. With shows like this it’s important to go in with an open mindset and perhaps it will be the key to enjoyment. 
It’s important to keep in mind that PTE is an extremely eccentric project. While the manga is made entirely by one person the anime strays from the original to allow many different people the creative freedom to create whatever the hellthey felt like. There’s no pretence or any other form of trying too hard, just genuine expressions from people who love anime and other forms of media and want to show it through creations of their own. Sometimes it leads to hilarious parodies other times references that warp original through the distinct lens of Pop Team Epic. When there’s so much sincerity shining through every seam and frame I couldn’t gather the effort to be annoyed at it even when it wasn’t good.


You might rightfully point out that I haven’t been talking much about anime itself and more about the approach to it and intention behind it. That’s because I find it impossible to review such a unique project on it’s technical merits. I can describe you the jokes and styles of humour that you will be experiencing throughout the run but that will only serve to ruin the magic of the show.


When it comes to technical aspects all I can say is that the show is practically flawless. When PTE looks ugly it’s supposed to look ugly. When it looks cheap it’s cause if it wasn’t, it wouldn’t be nearly as funny and when it drastically switches the art styles it only serves to remind you that you’re watching a new segment from a fresh team. There’s nothing in it that I could categorize as a flaw cause I wouldn’t be able to prove that it can be improved upon.


Sorry for something so pointless but I wanted to get out my personal feelings on PTE and if it convinces anyone to give a shot all the better.

Hoshiiro Girldrop is another one of those animes that seems to be a stereotypical shoujo series about a girl and her senpai. Well, you wouldn't be wrong there.
Story: HG starts us off with Daichi, and how he must live with Sosogu, his childhood friend. The anime is standard, with Sosogu getting into many different situations, and with those, strengthening her relationship with Daichi. However, what this plot presents us is with multiple tropes, which sometimes work, and sometimes don't. The whole idol thing is reminiscent of Love Live, but with the undercover aspect like Magical Girl animes. In a way, HG is a kind oflovechild between idol and magical girl animes with its theme of trying to mask an identity. However, this masking is eventually interrupted when she must show Daichi who she really is. He then basically becomes her coach, and they strengthen their relationship that way, until they reach the final episode, where Daichi has finally remembered who Sosogu was, and the promise he had made.


Art: The art is fairly standard, maybe being a bit simplistic when compared to animes like it. However, the colours are very vibrant, and stand out, even when compared to the giants like Love Live and Madoka Magica. There isn't much to talk about for the art, but it is pretty standard.


Sound: HG boasts a great opening, amazing songs for the idol portion, and also a kick ass flute song for its episode previews. Also, Daichi's seiyuu really shows his emotion, especially in the first episode when he questions who Sosogu is. 


Character: Overall, the development of character with the relationships between Sosogu and Daichi are great. They start as "strangers", and build their way up as lovers. Sosogu's goal is to get the attention of Daichi, and possibly get him to remember who she is, but that only starts to come into play near the end of the first season. By the end, Daichi is willing to sacrifice everything in order to bring her back, which I feel to be a great change from the beginning. Overall, their characters were exactly what was needed, although a bit trope-ish.


Enjoyment: What can I say except that HG was very enjoyable. The script was well executed, and full of tropes for me to poke fun at.


Overall: HG was a solid anime, picking apart tropes and putting them back together in a way that seems trope-ish itself, but ends up becoming just what the series needed. I would recommend this anime.

There’s something to be said about being so dumb that you’re actually brilliant. Poputepipikku walks that line like few others. 
The skits in each episode range from deliberately dumb to surprisingly artsy. In fact, I don’t know if I’ve ever seen another series utilize as many different styles as Poputepipikku. Some of these segments appear to parody more popular shows/styles while others are completely original. All of them, though, are pretty cool.The music is far from the focus of the series, but it still plays an active role in keeping the audience engaged.
In short, watching Poputepipikku is like watching a snake slowly devour a mousein your 5th grade science class.You may find yourself wondering "What is the point of watching any of this?” That’s a good question, but ultimately not important. At the end of the day, you’ll admit that despite the overall bizarreness of the situation, it was kind of cool to see that stereotypical mouse saturated with anime tropes, then swallowed whole by the snake.

It’s said that a monkey produces shit every few minutes. It takes Pop Team Epic just 30 seconds. 
Pop Team epic is an anime that is frustrating, crude, insane and, most importantly, self-aware. It knows that it relies on comedy that appeals to the lowest common denominator, and you can’t help but laugh along with it. Once you’ve seen the first episode, you’ve seen it all; the series will never get any more profound, or deep, or meaningful. It will still rely on being one long, random meme, and you know what? That’s okay. Not every anime needs to be a grand, beautiful, philosophical venture.Sometimes it can just be stupid fun. And for what it lacks in insightfulness, it more than makes up for with sheer ridiculousness. 


Episodic in nature, each episode consists of two halves; the first has the protagonists, short and tall high-schoolers Popuko and Pipimi, voiced by female voice actors. The second is the exact same content, with minor changes to the skits- the catch being that the girls are voiced by male VAs. It’s obvious that the VAs love what they’re doing, each bringing a different feel to the characters, without feeling like they lose their essence. While the near-identical nature of each half initially felt like a farce, a few episodes in I was glad of it, as I never wanted the wild ride to end. 


Episodes are composed of short skits, lasting anywhere from 15 seconds to 5 minutes. Each feels unique (to say the least), even if the short and pointless nature of a fair few left me scratching my head. Various animation styles are used, keeping the content fresh and exciting. In more than one instance, I found myself laughing like a madman, wondering all the while just why (and what) I was experiencing. PTE is best experienced when putting your brain into power saving mode. 


With this anime, there is simply no middle-ground. If you love memes and stupid humour, you’ll love it. If you enjoy lavish animation, complex, thought-provoking plots, and well-written dialogue, you’ll despise it. Normally, it would take a few episodes to know whether you would like an anime or not. Here, it will take just one. Be warned, though; if you only watch one episode, you’ll be missing out on the killer opening, with a song that matches the show's tone perfectly, being an unashamedly pulse-pounding bit of electronica. 


Pop Team Epic is the epitome of “different strokes for different folks." Whether you think it’s a gift or affront to the medium, there’s no denying that it is as ambitious as it is lowbrow, an obvious labour of love that deserves to be experienced by any anime fan, even if just for a little while. The best that can be said of it is that it never loses sight of what it wants to be: an absurdist comedy that capitalises on silliness, laughing at itself as much as it provides the laughs for the audience. It’s entirely comfortable in its own skin, and for that, it is worthy of commendation, if not adoration.

Do you remember going on the internet a couple years ago and seeing bits and pieces of a simplistic manga posted on random forums like tumblr or 4chan, usually they had no context and the jokes seemed very outlandish but not over the top. If you remember that, chances are you already know what Pop Team Epic is.
The Manga started back in 2014, and 4 years later, we finally get an anime adaptation.
I see a lot of people label this series as "a shitpost" but that's really the most general (in my opinion, normie) interpretation of the series. It's subversive, anti-humor style was not somethingmany people were expecting, and due to that, many people are quick to dismiss the strange style of humor as "lol so random" or, again, a shitpost. I'd say the best comparison I could make to this show is the Eric Andre Show(and I'm not the first to say this), the show has that out there, over the top feeling that it has, but the humor in the Eric Andre show relies on the "shittyness" of it all, the same goes for Pop Team Epic. The manga and anime both constantly acknowledge how dumb the show can get, and take every opportunity they can to poke fun at some of the dumb tropes in anime, like the power of friendship, the cute animal sidekick, and stories that we've seen in other shows(this is usually the Space Cat Company skit in every episode).


In my opinion, I would say the series as a whole adapts the absurd style of the manga perfectly, unlike most 4 panel anime adaptations, the bulk of this show is mostly 30 sec. to 1 min. sketches that for the most part are lifted straight from the manga rather than take the characters from 4 panel manga and put them in 23 minute stories. Something that adds to the sporadic nature of the show is the multimedia side of it all with the show seamlessly having 2d and 3d sketches, puppet shows, a flipbook story, watercolor styled sketches, and even French Sketches. 


My main gripe is how lopsided the episodes can feel. Most episodes follow a similar format. You have the opening sketch, the long sketch(usually the Space Cat Company sketch, with the exception of the Bobnemimimmi sketch in episode 7), then the last 4 minutes is a few 30 sec. to 1 minute sketches. Throw in 2 Bobnemimimmi sketches and then you have the first part done, and then they repeat the episode with male voice actors with variations of the sketches we just saw. To the show's credit, they do put enough variation in the second part to justify watching those sketches again.


Overall, it's a solid show, and a show I wish I could recommend to others, but it's a very acquired taste show, not something the average anime fan can walk into and think it's good, it's something that you would probably already know going in how to feel since if you like that more absurd, shitty style of humor, you would've already heard of it.

Do you like memes? 
Do you like anime?
If yes, you'll love the show, it constantly references other anime and sometimes even video games, makes fun of anime tropes and breaks the fourth wall without fail and I consider that an accomplishment.
It's pretty self aware too and insults itself.
As for people who've read the web comic, the majority of the anime is just that, but, animated. They got some other animation studios, like one from France to make brand new content though, so there's new stuff even for older fans!
Something that I kinda disliked at the start, is that an episode is 10 minutes long, andthe other half is the same stuff but with male voice actors, it seemed kinda lazy but now I think it's pretty understandable considering that they had to make an anime out of a 4-panel manga.

Let's see... If you are a run of the mill seasonal anime fan you probably will not like this anime. As it has no real plot, character development, narrative, or even minuscule fan service. That being said this is one of the most enjoyable anime I've ever watched since it diverges from these cliches, and one thing PTE is, is original and creative. The first episode is chock full of mainstream references and cameos that any person who hasn't been under a rock for the past ten years will understand. Although as the series go on the references become a bit more obscure to thecommon internet goer. This is where PTE really goes all out and they're not afraid of the consequences with lawsuit enticing impressions and characters ripped straight from their franchise. 


The art is always something to be impressed about. Apart from the 2d skits with Popuko and Pipimi, we have others like Hellshake Yano, and the felt dolls, and PTE tales of old, and of course BET (Bob epic team). These all diverge in art styles and a very creative in how the animators use the medium to tell the nonsensical story. Sound plays very closely along the same lines with the audio changing quality to fit the medium its being used in. Also the changing voice every episode and every 12 min segment is a fresh take on character diversity and really how hearing different voice actors from other terrific anime can really bring these two to life.


Popuko and Pipimi are hilarious as a duo and never have a dull moment together. I believe that Pipimi's passive aggressive attitude and (sometimes) nonchalant reactions fit perfect with Popuko's insane short-temper and bloodlust towards every living creature and (inanimate) that annoys her. They are a great diverge from moe high school SOL high school girls we get every season and I hope we got LOTS more of these two in the future.


I never had a dull moment with this show really. The different skits (after which the episode is titled) are always interesting and different every episode. I think anyone can appreciate all the work and dark humor they fit into twelve minutes because quite frankly it's damn impressive.


Overall, if you like dark, nonsensical, extremely meta humor you will love Pop team epic. Don't go in expecting a plot advancement or anything to really "happen". Just be ready to kick back and laugh at the absurdity and moxie this show has. Try not to think about Hellshake yano too much. :3

For those who are wondering if they should see this anime, you need to first understand that this anime knows exactly what it's trying to be: a complete mishmash of out of this world  
randomness!!! If you go into this anime not understanding that, don't even waste your time because you will hate this series.
Story: There isn't one. Not even joking. There are some segments that try hash out a quick self contained story and even that may conclude randomly.
Animation/Art Design: The art style breaks away from the traditional anime style but also gives so many different variances of styles. This being a mishmashof randomness is also reflected in the animation as well.\n\n
Characters: Popuko and Pipimi are the main characters and are the prime focus of the series. They are here to carry along the memeable clusterfuck that is Poputepipikku. \n\n
Overall: 7/10 When i started this series, I was very weirded out by what was going on but I eventually grew into understanding that this anime is not meant to be taken seriously in the same light as something like Fullmetal Alchemist and that's ok. You can have the most out of line, far from left field craziness hurled at you within a 10 minute time frame and still pull some enjoyment out of it.

You will either hate or love this anime. I'm stuck at loving the show because I love anime that pokes at everything in our culture. If you can't handle 15 minutes of crazy, non sensible, and randomness, then you will hate this show. 
This show pokes at everything that you know, love, and cherish. (Almost nothing is safe.) Also the art and music direction with this anime is on point. Every studio needs to take notes about the many art styles this show has incorporated, some of them being truly amazing! I caught myself pausing and watching skits over again just because of the art.


Overall the experience was amazing and would love to do it again, but maybe take out Bob Team Epic...that skit gives me nightmares....


-9/10 Bloo

I feel like I should review this anime through the medium of Meme only...but, unfortunately, I'm not enough of an Edgyboi to pull that off.
Pop team epic is Sh*tposting the anime...is that enough...I think I should write more.
I think it's harsh to rate this anime in the same way I would any other, since it is, essential, a completely different medium. It's 'high Meme-art'. Because of the nature of this anime it is, therefore, really hard to value the usual attributes of story, art, sound & character...all of which vary wildly (depending on what the meme gods demand) and are sometimes intentionally poor (bob) toadd 'spice' to the memes. \n\n
As a result, I rank its enjoyment as very high (9) because I found myself grinning like a fool throughout but overall as a 6 because it is, most definitely, an acquired taste that, like memes, doesn't improve with repeated viewings.

So Pop Team Epic or Poputepipikku finished leaving me with one word.
"What"
What prompted me to start watching it was the fact that I recognised the characters from Discord emotes used on some servers so I decided to give it a watch. I know I said that leaving Pop team epic left me with the word "what" but it was also what I started with. It started off pretending as another anime which in fact caused me to turn it off thinking I was watching the wrong anime as the website showed its Japanese name and not Pop Team Epic as other sites have been referringit to until I saw someone used it's Japanese name and decided to actually watch it. Needless to say it was the Pop Team Epic that it advertised with the title card being interrupted by Popuko yelling: "I THINK NOT." What then drawn me in was the fact that she had a male voice.


I carried on watching and was then surprised by the references it had in the first 5 minutes. From Your Name, Pokemon, Chrono Trigger, Berserk and even Skyrim. As I watched, I learnt that it was sort of like Robot Chicken in the sense that the episode is made of different sketches, some being more absurd than funny however. Oh and then the episode ended 12 minutes in rolling the credits. Then the episode... started playing again? But then their voices were female. I actually skipped over but then learnt that the male and female runs of the episode had slight differences between them. They were there, believe me.... they're just hard to find and just made me think they did it so they could make them 'longer episodes.'


The art is simple though at some points they disguised the art as another anime for the purpose of making Popuko and Pipimi look out of place for comedic effect which sometimes worked. Sometimes it became deliberately horrifying for the purpose of the 'Bob team epic' sketches.


Now for enjoyment... that all really comes down to your sense of humour. I did find enjoyment in some sketches but found nothing in others for example there were cooking show sketches that made no sense to me. I know that the show was full to the brim with references but I guess I just didn't know them. 


I'm giving it a 6/10 mainly because I found the character designs pretty fun looking and enjoyed some of the sketches like the 'Hellshake Yano' sketch which wasn't actually animated but was instead shot with people holding sketchbooks and flipping through them.

It only took me the first episode to know what exactly in the god damn hell is going on in the start of our 2018. However, because I didn’t read the guidelines, my previous review was removed. Fair point, obviously. I originally thought I can give something for this community by creating a review for an anime that I found incredibly unique but I didn’t put so much effort into it and it made my review look more like a trolling rather than serious reviewing in the end. I’m not going to do the same thing with this one now. I know for sure aseries that has 12 episodes in average has to be reviewed after there are 4 episodes broadcasted, but I feel like I need to make this review even though there are only 2 of them airing right now, noted since Saturday, January 13, 2018. With that being said, here goes nothing.


There’s some real happening in the world of anime caused by a culture most famously known as ‘memes’,which came from our particular world of cyberspace called ‘The Internet’. Eventually, due to the massive interference of a certain society in the world wide web, it affects the society of real world. From such, it created what appears to be, which is the main point of our review, Pop Team Epic. Be wary of this anime, for this isn’t your average one. This anime is very absurd, if not surreal.


[MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD due to a lack of informations]


You might be confused by the first episode and dropped the whole show already with all your might. The first minutes of this Episode One we’re talking about doesn’t even show anything remotely close to the premise of this anime, which needless to say, is pretty much an act of ‘trolling’. It introduced us with the plot of an ordinary, average everyday high-school boy called Taira Daichi, who has a classmate of a girl called Hoshifuri Sosogu, which little did he know, is a celebrity idol. Judging from the animation and the decent 8/10 opening song, it looks like something quite promising. Lord were we fooled, because only a few minutes later, everything turns into a wreck.


Out of nowhere, the animation is completely changed. The characters, which were previously introduced are not there anymore, and instead being replaced by 2 Chibi girl characters wearing high school uniforms: the short one and the tall one, which both are ridiculously voiced by old men. The anime storytelling format changed into something like 2-minutes-per-episode show, where every single scene is played in every two minutes for no obvious reason. Unfortunately, Pop Team Epic doesn’t tell any particular stories whatsoever and just mocking any other anime references in the running while it got the chance; and even if the format looks like 5-to-10-seconds-per-story, the show is actually a 24-minutes broadcast. It generated another question for us: with the way Pop Team Epic goes, how did they manage to fill in the gap through the second half of the episode? The answer might shock you.


When the second half is running, they REPEATED the same scene where Daichi first showed up and introduced. They also repeated the same opening song. What we didn’t expect, however, is how they repeated the same scene where 2 Chibi characters showed up and goofed us up: they goofed us harder. They completely use the same EXACT scenes from the first half, only this time they used different voice acting, originally from a couple of baritone-pitched sailormen into a couple of adult voice actresses. They changed ONLY the voice acting. THAT’S IT. Nothing else. Wikipedia said that Mariana Trench is the deepest and lowest place where humanity can sink into. This anime show is evidently the living proof where we can sink even much lower and further than that.


Bob’s Epic Tea …… I mean, Pop Team Epic, is adapted from 4-cells manga. It doesn’t have that much of a premise, nor a point about the show worths to mention, apart from it’s just about 2 characters having fun. It doesn’t serve any purposes except for the comedy and the comedy itself. There’s nothing critical, philosophical and deep about Pop Team Epic. One must not expect anything from this, neither the viewer nor the anime producer, because it looks like even the anime producer is only doing this just for fun while being carefree about what they’re creating. Reminds me of that anime where the guy keeps parodying everything whenever he got the chance. The guy’s called Gin-san, by the way. That being said, here are my scores for the main elements of this show [to find out my opinion about this show, go to the Enjoyment section]:


                                                 Story: ?/10

Truth be told, there isn’t any form of storytelling here in this. As I mentioned before, Pop Team Epic is about 2 characters having fun, randomly and carefreely. Viewers aren’t meant to think nor are they to comprehend anything that’s going on in this show because this anime is doing everything randomly in order to create laughs. The story setting of Daichi and Sosogu called “Hoshiiro Girldrop” is a complete lie, but they keep telling in every episode preview at the end that it’s what we’ll get in the next episode. Also, even if it does tell any stories, it’s only 10 seconds long in average with the longest is variative. The last thing one would expect is for all of those stories to be constructed as a whole. 


                                             Character: 4/10

There are 2 characters you need to pay attention to, and the only ones that matters: Popuko, the yellow-colored ponytail-haired short-tempered short girl; and Pipimi, the purple colored long-haired tall girl. Both has the appearance of a high school girl and wear the usual high-school clothing of sailor-themed uniform, except for one thing: they both talked like sailormen. In episode one, we’re introduced to such characters voiced by such actors as the standard, but that’s not so. Because later on, in the second half, the couple of MC’s voice actors changed into a couple of MC’S voice actresses.


Although the lack of characters is to be said (mainly there are only 2 of it), both voice actors and actresses did a good job on the voice acting most of the time. They might sound pretty lazy and half-assed  at some point while doing it, but for such a half-assed voice acting, I admit they did a good job because their voice-acting is genuine. Otherwise, it wouldn’t be considered notable at all.


                                           Soundtrack: 6/10

It’s not to be expected. Surprisingly, Pop Team Epic has a small bag of good OSTs. The Opening song is incredibly catchy, whether it’d be the pop idol-ish song of the deceptive and misleading Hoshiiro Girldrop’s or the electronic ravish Pop Team Epic’s. The same can be said to the Ending song. The opening song of Pop Team Epic sounds like the beginning of something visually chaotic and remarkably unimaginable to be served as a form of comedic relief.  


As for the rest of it, clearly they’re not doing anything desultory. Only the thing is, the amount of song tracks used here is quite a few, but when there is one, they composed and created it very well. Either because the anime doesn’t use background OSTs quite often so they wouldn’t have to create too many song tracks and they can focus in perfecting each and every single tracks (if it actually matters to them just as much, looking by the way this anime is presented to be), or they did it on purpose because they’re just so good at it that they’re lazy.


                                           Animation: 7/10

Pop Team Epic has a diverse collection of animations. It’s been proven since the first episode where they played the opening song and introduced the arguably most despicable lie in the history of human, Hoshiiro Girldrop, in which the animation clip is beyond mesmerizing and unbelievable and it’d go without saying that each of the heroines in it have the potential of becoming a waifu material. So much efforts put into that opening that it doesn’t even look like anything remotely close to a farce. Not a lot of people know about this, but it also worths a mention that the people from Kamikaze Douga are the animators of Jojo’s Bizarre Adventure’s opening clips. 


From then on, every single one of their episodes features a variety of clips, Be it the weirdly disgusting animation skit of Bobunemimimmi or the French live-action skit of Japon Mignon. These kinds of efforts shown is Pop Team Epic’s way of telling the viewers how much they’re absolutely capable of doing in creating this anime by that of a smug. Allegedly, much like how it’s portrayed so far that Pop Team Epic looks like it was made by a group of jerkheads, their animation is primarily a professional-ish 2D consists of chibi-looking characters.

                                         Enjoyment: 8/10

This anime is enjoyable subjectively. Some would despise it and spit on it, some would love it to the ground. It actually depends on the comedic taste of each person. There’s a name for the kind of comedy Pop Team Epic has, and it is called “Anti-Humor Comedy”. 


As it is called, Anti-Humor comedy does not intend to serve anything humoric to the audience, which is the very intention of the comedy. It indirectly generates laughing materials to enjoy and thus becomes what considered to be a new type of humor for the audience. Mostly, this kind of comedy gives some particular sign of random surrealism in it. Much of it is incomprehensible and not easy to decipher. However, the audiences are not meant to question ‘why’. There isn’t anything behind it to find out about and there is no use in pointing out the details for the sake of the enjoyment itself. Instead, what they need to do is to question ‘what’, as opposed to ‘what is the purpose of them doing this?’ but to ‘what the heck are they think they’re doing?’.


Examples could be found in the infamous western TV shows such as Monty Python’s Flying Circus and The Eric Andre Show. As it premises, almost everything in the show is a part of incomprehensible comedy skits instead of showing any tiny fabric of genuine reality. If we are to take examples from well-known anime, the closest one we could ever get would be Nichijou. The only thing that excludes it from being an Anti-Humor is how any elements in Nichijou is actually quite relatable to us, be it from the characters interactions to each other or the story settings, which makes it “Surreal Comedy”. The similarity of Surreal comedy to Anti-Humor comedy makes Surreal comedy the best foundation to relate to. Despite the similar absurdities, however, Surreal comedy is still understandable and easily laughable to the majority of audience due to the built associations between them and the show. Pop Team Epic obviously shows a huge gap between itself and that.


They also did many parodying. They parodied  a typical pop idol anime by using fake opening song and intro of one , which is later on to be known as Hoshiiro Girldrop.It doesn’t just stop there, because they parodied many anime shows after that as if it doesn’t care how many 4th walls they break and the consequences of it. Just in episode one, they already parodied and made many references such as Kimi no Na Wa, Pokemon, Berserk, Totoro, and Jojo’s Bizarre Adventure.


These kinds of comedies are very minor and unpopular because of the incomprehensibility and the nonsenseness of it. Needless to say, Pop Team Epic created a very good one and I’m gladly willing to give this show’s rate of Enjoyment a strong 9/10, for its mutifariousness of anti-humoric jokes and liberties of parodying. However, I have to be objective for the readers of my review. Which is why I can give this 8/10. That's as low as I can get.


                                           Overall: 7.5/10

In this modern society of 21st century, men-children and women-fujoshis, wherever they are, all participate in it. We live in the very age of raising awareness to infinite possibilities where everything can work. A businessman could become a leader in a country of power, nerds can have friends and become filthy rich, and people can trash each others and talk smack from far far away using the so-called "Discord Voice Chat" to establish a person as that of a lisped Ethiopian retard. Eventually, it created Pop Team Epic in the middle of it. This anime is created from memes. It’s stupid, unforgivable, unacceptable, nonsensical, idiotic, abusive, derogative, absolutely low, disrespectful, stupid, world-tier threatening, brain-consuming, carcinogenic, tumoric, hemorrhagic and a source of agoraphobic existential crisis. Have I mentioned that this anime is also stupid?


And yet, I’m feeling lucky and thankful.


I’m feeling lucky to start my 2018 with something out of the norm such as Pop Team Epic. It doesn’t want to follow other formulas of comedy anime like Osomatsu-san or Gintama. It’s not afraid to be different. It really wants to stand out as the center of attention like an attention whore it is. It holds a megaphone in hand while butt-naked, being watched by everyone including women and children, and shouts: “I’m f****** retarded!”.


I’m feeling thankful that, after many many ecchi-harem anime later (looking at you, To-Love-Ru and DxD), I finally can have something so special that I can personally look back to and said: “This is absolutely memorable and historical because it’s not like any others. I shall keep and preserve it”. I could never begin to imagine at any moment that it’d be something I’d grin to, smile to or laugh to.


At the end of the day, we all laugh to our stories and everything that’s around. Whether it’d be about the TV show we watched or about the times when we’re feeling down in high school. The real question is: “will it be a sad laugh or a heartful laugh?”

Poputepipikku has finally finished today. That was a personally terrible experience. Alright, so this show is about the absurd antics of two girls. They have names, but that doesn't really matter. This show was very hyped this season. Mostly because of the various memes coming out of it even before its announcement. You know those two girls, one with blue hair, and the one with orange hair but shorter then the other? Both flipping you off? That's what I'm talking about with this show. Just like what we started off with, this show is more of that. This show is like watching memes. There isa lot of different styles in this show, many of which are one offs. These can range to very creative, to very disgusting, but that's depending on what you like. It also gets very meta with itself, depicting references to other things as well as itself. I should also mention that there are effectively 2 versions of the show. There is a version where the girls are voice acted by girls, and another version where the girls are voice acted by men. Just to keep in mind when it plays twice and you don't know why. This adds to the absurdity.\n\n
There are multiple reasons I don't enjoy myself when watching this show. But it mainly boils down to the, "watching memes" portion I mentioned earlier. I don't like to watch random absurdity without any structure behind it. One segment is very different from the last. I understand that many people like this sort of thing, but I, for one, do not. In the later episodes, there is a sort of a story within it, which is the only part of the show I enjoy. But after that one off story is over, then it goes back to what it was doing before. Memes. I give Poputepipikku 3 out of 10. I hate it personally, but the greater masses will enjoy it I'm sure. So I recommend it to everyone that likes random things thrown at them. This has been your spoiler free but not really review on Poputepipikku.

If you've read Poputepipikku turn up the comedy by a few notches, if you haven't you are not missing much going into the anime.
The comedy is as mindless as it looks, most skits are short but just about every single one is a reference to pop culture/anime/video games/memes/etc. Some jokes went over my head but still got a chuckle out of me, I imagine everyone felt this way while watching Poputepipikku. Where the show shines in over the 4-panel manga is the animation. Many different studios work on various skits ranging from nicely drawn, poorly drawn, CGI, live acting, and even puppets. The episodes areshort and end at the half-way mark the rest is a re-run with different voice actors (Female first, male second). Some lines are written differently and some skits are done entirely different, so expect to see a gif or two online of a scene you may not recognize as it could have been from the second half of the episode.\n\n
Overall Poputepipikku isn't terrible if you consume a decent amount of Japanese culture, as you will pick up on some of the jokes. If anything it's a good anime to use for killing time since they're short.

"Pop Team Epic is greentext turned into anime"
-José Altozano
I'm an arts student. My college education gave me a greater insight of visual media as I returned to anime once again after six years away from it. If I had to make an art analogy of Pop Team Epic, it would be the Jackson Pollock of anime. Pop Team Epic CANNOT be reviewed by the conventional standards of anime because it's an unconventional anime. Trying to talk about "story" or "characters" in PTE would be like trying to analyze structure, use of color or linear narrative in a Joan Miró painting. It's like saying modern artis bad because even a child can do it. Well, do it then.\n\n
Pop Team Epic consists of various short sketches made by different studios or creators, and one longer sketch that gives the episode its title. This is not adapting a four panel manga. This is bringing the world together through humor, referential and/or meta; through various styles and creators. Pop Team Epic is about bringing anime to everyone, getting over foreign publishers and shake Hell itself. In a world where anime is becoming mainstream, Pop Team Epic offers itself to the world, not by Netflix or social commentaries, but by what bring us together in the first place: The Internet. Shitposts, absurd, referential, meta humor. None of us would be in this site without the Internet. And neither would be Pop Team Epic. Just look at the opening, where Popuko and Pipimi spin, changing into outfits of various eras and countries.\n\n
In conclusion, Pop Team Epic is a declaration of intentions in a new era for anime, defying its own medium, aware of the coming future. It will never be a masterpiece, maybe it won't be remembered, but it's an anime ahead of its time, and I will defend its intentions to the end. Mark my words, one day there will be an anime that will be what Pop Team Epic tried to be, but only because the world will be ready for it. But as long as there are people who underestimate it for being unconventional, we won't be ready.

The anime used all its hype up in the first few episodes.
Gradually as time goes on, it grew to be boring.
I think that some of the movie references seem out of place- it kind of ruins the feel of pop team epic. The 'Bob Team Epic' thing shouldve never been in the series in the first place. First of all:
-The really sketchy, rushed art style doesn't make it any funnier, it makes it a pain to watch.
-The awkward voice acting doesn't help
- It's cringey, nowhere even close to funny.
Its basically a complete mess- the clips and stories don't really fit together sometimes- if you wantit to flow actually link references, etc. \n
The way they tried too hard on the story line is quite appalling- even a basic, slice of life-like story line with a some over-exaggeration would've been effective.\n\n
Its a shame because the manga was actually pretty funny- yet they pretty much ruined it.

This anime is hilarious, and is surprisingly enjoyable. I mean... for an anime that doesn’t have any plot or character development, it’s very entertaining to watch!
The story doesn’t make any sense because because there is no story. There are only funny shorts.
Every short has its own style, but the main one is probably the least good one. 
The worst part about this anime are characters. There are only two of them, and neither have any backstory or motives. You could notice that they behave similar in every episode, but the only thing that comes to mind is “the short one is angry” and “the longone is calm”. That’s all that you are going to remember about the characters, even if you really try. \n
The best part about this series are the jokes. Most of them are hilariously funny. Even if you don’t like the style and hate shows with bad character development — watching this is going to entertain you. \n
Overall it’s a good show, that should not be taken seriously, or you will end up hating it.

I haven’t seen a good comedy like this since “Hataraku Maou-sama” I’ve read the manga and was desperately waiting for an animation for that bubbly and giggly feeling the manga gave me. I love how they don’t just stick to one style, animation wise. Sometimes they use a fine and neat style and other times, the style is a little sloppy and messy looking like when they do the “Bob Epic Team”
The first episode totally put me off, though! It kinda tricks you into thinking it’s a completely different show then it cuts that all off and then that’s when the weird starts!
I think everyonewill enjoy this one!
